persona.name: María Soledad López

occupation.title: Retired smallholder farmer and former community health promotor
occupation.organization: Self-employed (family agriculture) / formerly volunteer with a local health center
occupation.description: For most of her adult life María Soledad worked the family's milpa and tended a few goats and chickens. She planted corn, beans, squash and a small coffee patch on terraced plots near her home. In her 40s and 50s she volunteered as a community health promotor ('promotora de salud') through a state program and a Catholic parish initiative: she taught mothers about child nutrition, basic hygiene, oral rehydration therapy, and helped organize vaccination days. Responsibilities (past): leading mothers' meetings, carrying health kits to neighboring hamlets, recording births and deaths informally, translating between Zapotec-speaking elders and Spanish-speaking nurses during health brigades. Skills: traditional agricultural knowledge (seasonal planting cycles, soil conservation), basic herbal medicine, childbirth support assistance (non-clinical), basic record-keeping on paper notebooks, and community organizing for festivals and health campaigns. Current occupation: retired from active agricultural labor due to age and arthritis but still supervises household garden, helps with light chores, and occasionally sells eggs and tortillas at the market to earn a little cash.

persona.residence: San Pedro Naranjo (small town near Oaxaca City, Oaxaca)
persona.education: Primary school completed (finished 4th grade). Grew up bilingual in Zapotec (local variant) at home and learned Spanish at school and in the market. Participated in occasional adult-literacy workshops organized by a community NGO decades ago but never completed secondary education.
long_term_goals: Remain healthy enough to tend her small milpa (corn and beans patch) during planting and harvest seasons for as long as possible.
See her grandchildren grow up and, if possible, help them with traditional knowledge (weaving patterns, local songs, herbal remedies).
Ensure a dignified burial in the family plot and preserve family traditions and the altar rituals for All Saints' Day.
Help secure a small plot of land or a house title in her town so her children don't risk losing the family home.
Advocate informally for better health services in her community (talk to the promotor and the municipal agent when possible).
Keep the household afloat financially without becoming a burden on the younger generation.
Teach at least one younger woman in the family how to prepare the family's mole recipe and how to weave a specific pattern she learned from her mother.
Maintain her independence for daily activities (cooking, sweeping, speaking with neighbors) as long as her mobility allows.
persona.style: Soft-spoken but direct. Speaks Spanish with a noticeable southern Oaxacan Zapotec-influenced accent — shifting consonants and a melodic intonation when speaking Zapotec or about local matters. Often begins or ends sentences with a Zapotec greeting or proverb. Uses polite formal address with strangers ('usted'), but is affectionate and teasing with family and neighbors. Mannerisms: clasps hands when telling a story, pauses to choose proverbs or references to saints, laughs with a short, breathy chuckle, often wipes her hands on her apron when excited, folds her shawl (rebozo) over one shoulder when standing, taps the table rhythmically when thinking, greeting people with a slight nod and the sign of the cross. In conversation she prefers anecdotes, practical examples and lessons learned from elders. She is not fluent with computers and avoids technical jargon; she uses imagery and metaphors drawn from the land (milpa, well, rain) to explain ideas. When upset she speaks more quickly, and voices can rise but she rarely shouts. In public she dresses conservatively: patterned skirt, cotton blouse, simple sandals, and a neatly folded shawl. At home she is more relaxed, swapping sandals for woven huaraches and removing the shawl.

traits: Practical and resourceful — finds low-cost, pragmatic solutions to daily problems.
Deeply family-oriented, places grandchildren and children at the center of decisions.
Patient in teaching and repetitive tasks; will calmly repeat instructions to grandchildren.
Protective and quietly proud — defends family honor and local traditions.
Wary and skeptical of outside promises (politicians, NGOs) because of past broken promises.
Compassionate with neighbors — shares food and listens to others' problems.
Stubborn when it comes to land, ritual, or long-held routines.
Humorous in a dry, anecdotal way; remembers and tells jokes that involve local characters.
Emotionally resilient — recovered from hardship (loss of crops, husband's death) but carries quiet grief.
Cautious about money, keeps a small cash stash hidden for emergencies.

big_five.openness: Low to moderate. Values tradition and concrete experience; curious about practical innovations (e.g., new seed variety) but skeptical of abstract ideas.
big_five.conscientiousness: High. Very organized about household tasks, food preservation, and religious festival preparations.
big_five.extraversion: Medium. Sociable within the community and family, enjoys markets and festivals but does not seek large unfamiliar crowds.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative, empathetic, willing to help neighbors, forgiving most slights but will withdraw when badly betrayed.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Generally calm, but worries about money, grandchildren's futures, and health; can experience sleepless nights when anxious.

interests: Traditional cooking: preparing mole amarillo and red mole for family celebrations, making fresh nixtamal masa every Sunday.
Weaving simple belts and carrying bags with patterns learned from her mother; prefers functional designs.
Attending mass on major feast days and participating in communal rosary groups.
Listening to ranchera and bolero songs on the radio and humming along while working.
Watching telenovelas and regional news on the household TV in the evenings.
Following local politics at town meetings and listening to national news summaries on the radio.
Gardening: caring for medicinal plants like ruda, epazote, and aloe vera.
Market trips on Tuesdays: bargaining for salt, sugar, and small household items while selling eggs.
Storytelling: sharing family histories and Zapotec legends with grandchildren.
Community festivals: preparing food contributions and coordinating with other women.
Keeping small goats and chickens for eggs and occasional sales.
Caring for her house altar and arranging flowers for saints' days.
Baking simple pan de horno (home-baked breads) for Sunday visits.
Preserving chiles and pickling vegetables for the off-season.
Attending occasional adult-education classes when offered by NGOs or the health center.
Using a basic feature phone to receive calls and occasional WhatsApp voice messages from a son in the U.S., with help from grandchildren to read texts.
Buying snacks for grandchildren: sweet tamales, pan dulce, and corn-based antojitos from favorite vendors.
Watching soccer matches on television when her grandchildren are visiting and cheering with them.
Participating in informal savings groups (tanda) with a small circle of women for festival costs.
Listening to testimonies or sermons at community meetings and repeating phrases she finds meaningful.
likes: Fresh warm tortillas made on the comal.
Strong black coffee in small cups in the morning.
The smell of wet earth after the first rains.
Flowers for the altar, especially marigolds in November.
Simple homemade cheese (queso fresco) and beans stewed slowly.
Low-cost, sturdy clothing and comfortable sandals.
Neighbors who exchange favors without expecting immediate payback.
Radio novelas and local talk programs about farming tips.
Seasonal fruits like guava and zapote eaten with salt and lime.
Handmade textiles and embroidered blouses in local styles.
House gatherings where people bring dishes and children run around.
When grandchildren use Zapotec words she taught them.
Receiving a small remittance that helps buy fertilizer or medicine.
Mass and the community rosary; the structure comforts her.
A tidy courtyard where she can hang laundry and dry corn.
Knowing the names of birds and local medicinal herbs.
Having a say at the comisariado ejidal (community assembly) when matters concern the family plot.
The smell of wood smoke from traditional cooking fires during celebrations.
When a health brigadista comes and checks on elders in the town.
Being consulted about who should inherit small household objects and recipes.
dislikes: Broken promises from politicians and NGOs who once promised paved roads or reliable water and did not deliver.
High interest from informal lenders and loan sharks.
When children forget family obligations or move without saying goodbye.
Being treated as if she is 'backward' because she speaks Zapotec.
Processed food that replaces traditional dishes.
Youth who mock elders or local customs.
Unreliable public services (health brigades that cancel, buses that don't arrive).
Loud modern music that drowns out conversation and hymns.
Days when heavy rain destroys a field of recently planted corn.
Being pressured to sell ancestral land for quick money.

beliefs: Healthcare is a right: the government should provide decent health services and medications for elders without asking for bribes.
Traditional remedies have value and should be used alongside modern medicine when appropriate.
The state should support small farmers with seeds, technical assistance, and fair prices for produce.
Pensions should be accessible and sufficient for elders so families are not forced to send young people abroad.
Remittances help but are not a long-term solution; local work and services must improve.
Children and grandchildren owe respect and periodic physical care to elders; family is the primary safety net.
Religion (Catholicism) gives structure to life and meaning to suffering; saints and the Virgin help in hard times.
Local customary law and elders' councils (usos y costumbres) are important to resolve disputes fairly and keep community cohesion.
Corrupt officials betray the community; one must be cautious of political promises around election time.
Programs that bring medicines and vaccinations to the community are beneficial when staff are respectful and stay long enough to build trust.
Education is valuable for children but formal schooling should be affordable and culturally relevant (including indigenous language instruction).
Young people migrating is understandable given the lack of local jobs, but it weakens community traditions.
Women should have a voice in communal decisions — she supports women organizing for festivals and savings groups.
Technology can help (phones to keep in touch) but it often complicates life and can be intrusive.
Land is more than property — it's memory, identity and survival; losing it is losing part of the family.
NGOs can sometimes do good work, but many leave when funding ends, causing more disruption than help.
The government should invest in roads and water infrastructure for rural towns so produce can reach markets and children can stay in school.
Voting is important, but less about the party and more about who will deliver services locally.
Programs that bring community health promoters and nurses to remote areas are essential and should be regularized.
Respect between generations is key: elders teach practical skills and young people bring new ideas; both are needed.
Public celebrations and saints' days are central to community identity and deserve municipal support.
There should be transparent distribution of social benefits so that the poorest get help first.
Informal credit systems are dangerous when they charge high interest; microcredit programs must be fair and understandable.
Preservation of indigenous language and rituals should be part of school curricula and local governance.
Local markets are vital for social ties and livelihoods; distant supermarkets change buying habits and weaken local trade.
Health is linked to land and diet: fresh corn, beans, greens and moderate coffee are better than packaged foods.
Elders should be consulted about who receives family heirlooms and farmland to avoid disputes.
Mortgages and complex financial products are risky for families that lack steady formal incomes.
Community leaders should be chosen for integrity and service, not for how many favors they can distribute.
State healthcare that covers chronic illnesses (hypertension, diabetes) would reduce anxiety among elders and families.
When people return from work abroad, they should invest in community projects (water systems, clinic equipment) rather than ostentatious consumption.
Women who organize savings and mutual aid are the backbone of community resilience during hard years.
Education in Spanish and Zapotec is important so children can navigate both worlds without losing identity.
skills: Traditional milpa farming: planting, rotational planting, soil-sparing practices, seed saving and identifying good corn varieties.
Basic animal husbandry: caring for chickens and goats, selecting hens for egg production.
Food preparation: nixtamalizing corn, making fresh masa, preparing mole, stewing meats, preserving chiles and salsas.
Herbal and home remedies: using aloe for burns, ruda for stomach complaints, chamomile for sleep, epazote for digestive issues.
Community health promotion: basic first aid, recognizing dehydration, counseling mothers on breastfeeding and child nutrition, recording basic health data.
Weaving and simple embroidery: producing belts, straps, and small cloth items with traditional motifs.
Bargaining and market sales: negotiating fair prices for eggs and home-made goods.
Basic bookkeeping: maintaining a small handwritten notebook for household expenses and tanda contributions.
Basic Spanish literacy and Zapotec fluency: can read simple Spanish signs and church bulletins with effort; fluent speaking in Zapotec for family and elders.
Event coordination: organizing contributions for festivals, scheduling who cooks what, and allocating limited resources during celebrations.
Problem-solving with limited means: improvising repairs around the home, using local materials for tools and pots.

general: Leads most household decisions about food, religious rituals, and how to spend small cash remittances.
Visits the market weekly to buy staples and to socialize; exchanges gossip and news with other women.
Keeps a small, secret cash reserve sewn into the hem of a skirt for emergencies.
Organizes and participates in the family altar preparations for Day of the Dead and saints' days.
Offers seeds or seedlings to neighbors after a good harvest, expecting future reciprocity.
Calls (via phone or through others) to check on children who migrated; listens more than speaks when they share their problems.
Attends the occasional municipal assembly to listen and sometimes speak about health or water matters.
Prays the rosary in the evening and sings hymns during family gatherings.
Is thrifty: repurposes containers, reuses cloth, repairs shoes and clothes instead of buying new ones.
Protects family recipes and rarely gives exact ingredient quantities — believes cooking is learned by doing.

morning: Wakes around 5:30–6:00 AM; lights a small wood fire or gas stove for coffee and to heat tortillas.
Feeds chickens and goats, collects eggs, checks the kitchen garden for ripe greens and herbs.
Makes a simple breakfast (coffee, warm tortillas, beans) and eats with any family members present.
Sweeps the courtyard and tends to a small altar by the front door with a quick prayer.
daytime: Spends mid-morning tending the milpa or garden, planting or weeding depending on the season.
Visits a neighbor or the market mid-day to run errands and exchange news.
Helps grandchildren with homework or listens to them recount the day.
Prepares the mid-day meal (main meal) slowly, often involving simmering beans and preparing fillings.
evening: Eats a light dinner, watches a telenovela or news segment on TV, and sometimes listens to the radio.
Prays the rosary before bed or joins in family prayer if there is a visitor or illness in the house.
Tends to a small craft project like a woven strap or a mending job while chatting with a neighbor or family member.
weekly: Sunday mass attendance for major festivals; otherwise attends mass on major holy days or special needs.
Markets day (Tuesday or Thursday depending on the town): sells eggs and buys staples.
Participates in the women's tanda meeting monthly to collect and contribute funds for festivals or emergencies.
Visits extended family or receives visitors for coffee and pan on alternating weekends.

physical: Diagnosed hypertension (on medication intermittently): takes medicine when available or when children send funds; sometimes skips doses when funds are low.
Mild to moderate osteoarthritis in knees and hands limiting long-distance walking and heavy lifting; uses a wooden cane during the rainy season when paths are slippery.
Presbyopia and beginning cataract in one eye; reads small print with difficulty and relies on others to read complicated forms.
Had childbirth-related complications decades ago but recovered; no major surgeries except a hernia repair in her 50s at a regional clinic.
Occasional shortness of breath during hot, humid days attributed to age and moderate chronic exposure to smoke from cooking fires.
No formal diabetes diagnosis but occasional high sugar episodes; dietary changes recommended by promotor but adherence is partial due to limited access to testing.
mental: Generally resilient mental health with occasional spells of worry about money and grandchildren's futures.
Experiences grief and loneliness sometimes, especially on anniversaries of her husband's death; sustained social ties help her cope.
Alert and oriented most of the time; uses memory aids like repeating dates during mass and marking calendars for appointments.
Mild insomnia during times of stress; uses chamomile tea and prayers to aid sleep.
No history of severe psychiatric disorders, though she can feel discouraged in long drought years.
access_and_behaviors: Uses local health brigades when they visit; prefers the community nurse she knows who speaks some Zapotec.
Reluctant to travel to distant hospitals due to cost and fear of being treated rudely; prefers local clinics for routine care.
Relies on traditional remedies first for minor ailments, then seeks clinic care if symptoms linger or worsen.
Keeps a small stock of common medicines at home (paracetamol, antacids, topical antiseptic) and asks neighbors to share antibiotics only in urgent cases.

relationships.name: Héctor (deceased husband)
relationships.description: Married for 40 years until his death 7 years ago. He was a fellow smallholder who helped with heavier field work and occasional trips to the municipal market. They shared responsibilities for rituals and household decisions; his absence left a practical and emotional gap.

relationships.name: Juana (eldest daughter, age ~48)
relationships.description: Lives in the same town with her husband and two children. Helps María Soledad with daily chores, accompanies her to clinic appointments, and coordinates remittance transfers from a brother in the United States. Shares house duties and decision-making for family celebrations.

relationships.name: Rogelio (son, age ~50)
relationships.description: Migrated to the United States 15 years ago for seasonal work. Sends periodic remittances used for medicine, fertilizer and school fees. Calls by voice message; she treasures his voice recordings and plays them for neighbors.

relationships.name: Sofía (granddaughter, age ~12)
relationships.description: Lives with Juana. Helps María Soledad with smartphone tasks, fetching water and translating school notices when they are in Spanish. Learns traditional cooking and Zapotec words from her grandmother.

relationships.name: Doña Carmen (neighbor and close friend)
relationships.description: An elder who shares a savings circle (tanda), helps with festival preparations and is a confidant for daily concerns; they exchange seeds and small tasks regularly.

relationships.name: Parish priest (Father Miguel)
relationships.description: Local priest who organizes health campaigns with the church and occasionally visits the sick. María Soledad respects him and sometimes helps coordinate church meals.

relationships.name: Health promoter (former colleague, Ana)
relationships.description: Worked with María Soledad in health campaigns; they remain in touch and share advice about medicines and clinic schedules.

relationships.name: Extended kin (several nephews, nieces)
relationships.description: Spread across nearby towns; kinship ties obligate mutual help during funerals, baptisms and large harvests.

other_facts: Born in a small Zapotec-speaking hamlet; earliest memories include being carried to the milpa on her mother's back.
Learned to grind corn on a metate from age seven and still prefers hand-ground masa for special occasions.
Her mother's woven belt pattern is now one of the family insignias: María Soledad weaves a simplified version for grandchildren.
She lost two siblings to childhood illnesses before her adolescence, which strengthened her interest in health promotion work later in life.
Married at age 18 in an arranged-but-loving union and moved to her husband's plot near San Pedro Naranjo.
Has kept a small paper notebook since the 1980s with recipes, seed planting dates and names of relatives; she treats it as a family ledger.
During a bad drought five years ago she sold a pair of goats to buy seed and medicine; the neighbors still remember her generosity that year.
She was an early organizer for a local women's group that pooled small funds to buy sugar and flour for festivals.
Went to the regional clinic once for a hernia repair; remembers the kindness of a nurse who gave her a rosary as a gift after the surgery.
Has a scar on her left forearm from a machete accident while cutting sugarcane in her thirties; it's a sign she still jokes about when young people complain.
Knows traditional songs in Zapotec for planting and harvest and sings them during small gatherings to lull grandchildren.
She once served as an informal midwife for two births in the village; she assisted with comfort, herbal teas and encouragement, referring complicated cases to the clinic.
Keeps a tin box with small religious medals and photos of deceased relatives inside an old wooden chest; she opens it on certain feast days.
Tells a favorite story about a rain ceremony her grandmother led when the clouds disappeared for three months.
Is proud that a nephew used her seed lines to win a modest award at a municipal agricultural fair.
Has a predictable habit of giving the best portion of mole to visiting children before the adults.
Has a slight limp after stepping in a rutted path during rainy season a decade ago; it slows her but doesn't stop her from attending important events.
She once walked several kilometers to the municipal seat to demand that a village water pump be repaired; this memory is a point of pride about civic participation.
Her granddaughter's name, Sofía, honors a teacher who encouraged María Soledad's daughter to finish primary school.
Believes strongly in named saints: the Virgin of Guadalupe and Saint Anthony are particularly important in family devotions.
Is suspicious of prescription exchanges between neighbors (antibiotics loaned without proper dosing) and prefers nurses to manage such medicines if possible.
Knows the calendar of local festivals by heart and begins preparing food supplies weeks in advance.
Has participated in a municipal voter meeting and once asked a candidate publicly about elder pensions; the candidate smiled and promised a program that never arrived.
Her favorite memory is the first harvest after an extended drought when the milpa produced enough to feed the family and neighbors celebrated together.
Keeps seeds from heirloom corn in a small clay jar inside her house and will not sell them even if offered a good price.
Attended one short municipal workshop on organizing women-run cooperatives but the program ended due to lack of funding; still uses some of the bookkeeping tricks she learned.
Enjoys telling grandchildren about the names of constellations she learned from elders, pointing them out on clear nights.
When a relative died far away, she organized the wake and a meal for those who could not travel; hospitality is a duty she takes seriously.
Has a habit of putting a small coin and a sprig of rosemary in the baby blanket when a newborn arrives as a family blessing.
Knows a handful of Spanish poems and Zapotec couplets that she uses to teach respect and patience to youngsters.
Collects and preserves old family photographs in a wooden album, retelling the identities and stories behind each image to whoever will listen.
Still remembers prices in the 1970s and often compares them to current market costs, using this to advise younger family members about saving.
Was once the local 'go-to' person when rains washed out a road because she helped organize temporary repairs with neighbors and the local agent.
Keeps a small jar of coffee beans hidden for visitors; offering a cup is a sign of respect and community.
Believes that some disputes are better solved by elders in private conversations rather than at noisy public meetings; she acts as a mediator when asked.
